newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West power flat to higher amid heating demand.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West power flat to higher amid heating demand.

text.p: Spot power prices in the U.S. West were flat to slightly higher amid increased heating demand in the Northwest, market sources said Thursday.
"It's been dipping into the upper 30s (degrees) and foggy," said a Portland, Ore.-based trader. "Our system loads are up."

For Friday pre-schedulings, the Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) raised firm and non-firm offers during off-peak hours for all delivery points by $1.00 to $2.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) to $17.00.
Traders also cited higher natural gas prices and continued constraints on transmission from the Northwest to the Southwest as helping to support spot power prices.
"Availability isn't that great," said a Southwest trader. "A lot of surplus sales have already been made. Generators with extra power are using gas, which is higher-cost."
Next-day spot quotes for firm, peak deliveries at the California-Oregon border (COB) were unchanged at $19.25-19.50 per MWh.
Friday peak quotes at Mid-Columbia were $17.50-18.00, with off-peak close behind at $16.00-16.50.
Palo Verde electricity for Friday delivery was last quoted $20.00-23.00, up from $20.00-20.50.
Palo Verde for November was higher at $17.00-17.50, compared with $16.80-17.25 on Wednesday. November COB was quoted close to $18.00, up from $17.45-17.60 on Wednesday.
